title: Barnes Jewish Hospital Stroke Dysphagia Screen
description: Assesses ability to swallow without aspiration after stroke. This screening tool helps identify stroke patients at risk for dysphagia and aspiration, allowing safe initiation of oral intake while preventing aspiration complications.

parameters.name: gcs_less_than_13
parameters.description: Is the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) less than 13?

parameters.name: facial_asymmetry
parameters.description: Is there facial asymmetry or weakness present?

parameters.name: tongue_asymmetry
parameters.description: Is there tongue asymmetry or weakness present?

parameters.name: palatal_asymmetry
parameters.description: Is there palatal asymmetry or weakness present?

parameters.name: water_test_performed
parameters.description: Was the water swallow test performed? (Only if all preliminary questions are NO)

parameters.name: throat_clearing_initial
parameters.description: Throat clearing during initial swallow (if water test performed)

parameters.name: cough_initial
parameters.description: Cough during initial swallow (if water test performed)

parameters.name: voice_change_initial
parameters.description: Voice change during initial swallow (if water test performed)

parameters.name: throat_clearing_delayed
parameters.description: Throat clearing 1 minute after swallowing (if water test performed)

parameters.name: cough_delayed
parameters.description: Cough 1 minute after swallowing (if water test performed)

parameters.name: voice_change_delayed
parameters.description: Voice change 1 minute after swallowing (if water test performed)

ranges.interpretation: Patient passed dysphagia screen. Can be started on regular diet. Continue to monitor for any changes in swallowing ability.
Patient failed dysphagia screen. Keep NPO (nothing by mouth) and refer to Speech-Language Pathology for comprehensive swallowing evaluation before initiating oral intake.

references: Edmiaston J, Connor LT, Loehr L, Nassief A. Validation of a dysphagia screening tool in acute stroke patients. Am J Crit Care. 2010 Jul;19(4):357-64. doi: 10.4037/ajcc2009961.

Donovan NJ, Daniels SK, Edmiaston J, Weinhardt J, Summers D, Mitchell PH; American Heart Association Council on Cardiovascular Nursing and Stroke Council. Dysphagia screening: state of the art: invitational conference proceeding from the State-of-the-Art Nursing Symposium, International Stroke Conference 2012. Stroke. 2013 Apr;44(4):e24-31. doi: 10.1161/STR.0b013e3182877f57.
formula: Screen fails if ANY preliminary question is YES OR if water test shows ANY signs of aspiration (throat clearing, cough, or voice change during or after swallowing)
notes: Designed for use by non-speech pathology trained healthcare professionals
91-95% sensitive for detecting dysphagia and aspiration risk
Water test only performed if ALL preliminary questions are NO
Patient given 3 oz of water to drink in sequential swallows
Assess for symptoms both during initial swallow and 1 minute after
Any positive finding results in NPO status and speech pathology referral
